contextId.information: This speaks of Yahweh making the bad water pure as if he healed it. AT: "made the waters pure" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: healed these waters

contextId.information: this means that he will no longer be unclean. A person who God considers spiritually unacceptable or defiled is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. God considers a person who has leprosy as being defiled and unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you will be clean

contextId.information: A high ranking captain who was the king's personal assistant is spoken of as if he was a person on whom the king leaned his hand. AT: "the captain who was close to the king" or "the captain who was the king's personal assistant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the captain on whose hand the king leaned

contextId.information: Someone punishing the four men is spoken of as if punishment were a person who captures them. AT: "the people will punish us" or "someone will punish us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: punishment will overtake us

contextId.information: A high ranking captain who was the king's personal assistant is spoken of as if he were a person on whom the king leaned his hand. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:07:01|7:2]]. AT: "the captain who was close to the king" or "the captain who was the king's personal assistant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the captain on whose hand he had leaned

contextId.information: Yahweh causing much rain to fall in order to make the crops grow is spoken of as if Yahweh were opening windows in heaven through which he pours down rain. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:07:01|7:2]]. AT: "even if Yahweh were to cause much rain to fall from heaven" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: even if Yahweh should make windows in heaven

contextId.information: Ben Hadad was not actually Elisha's son, but Hazael called him that to show a close relationship between them. AT: "Ben Hadad, the king of Aram, who is like a son to you," (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Your son Ben Hadad king of Aram

contextId.information: Hazael is talking about himself. He speaks of his low status and lack of influence by comparing himself to a dog. Here a dog represents a lowly animal. AT: "I am as powerless as a dog" (UDB) or "I am as powerless as a lowly animal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He is only a dog

contextId.information: This speaks of Jehu committing the same sins that Jeroboam committed, as if Jeroboam's sins were a place that Jehu did not leave. AT: "did not stop committing the kinds of sins that Jeroboam son of Nebat had committed" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: did not leave the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat

contextId.information: The eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. AT: "what I judge to be right" or "what I consider to be right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: what was right in my eyes

contextId.information: This means that Jehu died. This speaks of him being buried where his ancestors were buried as if he were sleeping with them. AT: "Jehu died and they buried him in Samaria, where they had also buried his ancestors." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Jehu slept with his ancestors, and they buried him in Samaria

contextId.information: These men were previous kings of Judah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Jehoshaphat and Jehoram and Ahaziah, his fathers

contextId.information: Here stopping his sin is spoken of as if he turned away from them. This can also be stated in positive form. AT: "Jehoahaz did not stop doing the sins of Jeroboam" or "Jehoahaz continued to do the same sins as Jeroboam" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Jehoahaz did not turn away from them

contextId.information: Yahweh becoming angry with Israel is spoken of as if his anger was a fire that burned. AT: "Then Yahweh became very angry with Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The anger of Yahweh burned against Israel

contextId.information: To stop sinning is spoken of as if they departed from the sins. This can be stated in positive form. AT: "Israel did not stop doing the same sins as Jeroboam had done" or "Israel continued to commit the same sins as Jeroboam had committed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they did not depart from the sins of the house of Jeroboam

contextId.information: Being over the household represents having authority over those in it. AT: "was in charge of the household" or "had authority over those in Azariah's palace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: was over the household

contextId.information: The phrase "in his place" is a metaphor meaning "instead of him." AT: "became king instead of Azariah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: became king in his place

contextId.information: The sight of Yahweh represents Yahweh's judgment. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:03:01|3:2]]. AT: "what was evil in Yahweh's judgment" or "what Yahweh considers to be evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: what was evil in the sight of Yahweh

contextId.information: The sight of Yahweh represents Yahweh's judgment. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:03:01|3:2]]. AT: "what was evil in Yahweh's judgment" or "what Yahweh considers to be evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: what was evil in the sight of Yahweh

contextId.information: Departing from sins represents refusing to do those sins. AT: "Zechariah did not refuse to commit the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat" or "He sinned as Jeroboam son of Nebat had sinned" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he did not depart from the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat

contextId.information: The phrase "in his place" is a metaphor meaning "instead of him." AT: "became king instead of Menahem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: became king in his place

contextId.information: The sight of Yahweh represents Yahweh's judgment. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:03:01|3:2]]. AT: "what was evil in Yahweh's judgment" or "what Yahweh considers to be evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: what was evil in the sight of Yahweh

contextId.information: The phrase "in his place" is a metaphor meaning "instead of him." AT: "became king instead of Pekahiah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: became king in his place

contextId.information: The sight of Yahweh represents Yahweh's judgment. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:03:01|3:2]]. AT: "what was evil in Yahweh's judgment" or "what Yahweh considers to be evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: what was evil in the sight of Yahweh

contextId.information: The phrase "in his place" is a metaphor meaning "instead of him." AT: "became king instead of Pekah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: became king in his place

contextId.information: Being taken away represents being destroyed. AT: "were not destroyed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: were not taken away

contextId.information: The phrase "in his place" is a metaphor meaning "instead of him." AT: "became king instead of Jotham" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: became king in his place

contextId.information: He did not obey Yahweh's laws as given to Moses. "In the sight of" is metaphor for judgment or opinion. AT: "evil to Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: evil in the sight of Yahweh

contextId.information: "Walking" is metaphor for the ways or patterns of behavior people use in their lives. AT: "doing the activities" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: walking in the practices

contextId.information: To "sell themselves" is a metaphor for committing completely to do that which was evil. AT: "committed themselves to do things that Yahweh said were evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: sold themselves to do that which was evil in the sight of Yahweh

contextId.information: "He tore" is a metaphor for violent removal. AT: "Yahweh removed the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He tore Israel

contextId.information: "Sight" is a metaphor for attention and care. AT: "so Yahweh removed the people of Israel from his attention and care" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: so Yahweh removed Israel from his sight

contextId.information: "Listen" is a metaphor for paying attention and acting on the command. AT: "They did not obey" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They would not listen

contextId.information: "In the eyes" is a metaphor for Yahweh's attention and care. AT: "King Hezekiah did what was right to Yahweh" or "Hezekiah did things that Yahweh said are right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He did what was right in the eyes of Yahweh

contextId.information: To "hold on" is metaphor for staying loyal and attached. AT: "Hezekiah stayed loyal to Yahweh" or "Hezekiah remained faithful to Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he held on to Yahweh

contextId.information: The speaker is extending the metaphor by describing what happens when a reed is used as a support. AT: "but if someone uses this for support, he will be injured" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: but if a man leans ... and pierce it

contextId.information: These sources of food and water are metaphors for security and plenty. This also was a common way of expressing this idea. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: his own vine ... his own fig tree ... his own cistern

contextId.information: This a common way (an idiom) to use the action of lifting to metaphorically represent praying earnestly to Yahweh who is above us. AT: "pray earnestly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: lift up your prayer

contextId.information: The words "measuring line" and "plumb line" are metaphors for the standards Yahweh uses to judge people. AT: "judge Jerusalem using the same measure I used when I judged Samaria and the house of Ahab" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: stretch over Jerusalem the measuring line used against Samaria, and the plumb line used against the house of Ahab

contextId.information: "walked in all the ways that his father walked in." The way a person lives is spoken of as if that person were walking on a path. AT: "lived completely the way his father had lived" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: followed in all the way that his father had walked in

contextId.information: "He walked in all the ways of David his ancestor" Josiah behaving as David did is spoken of as if he walked on the same road or way as David. AT: "He lived the way David his ancestor had lived" or "He followed the example of David his ancestor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He walked in all the way of David his ancestor

contextId.information: Yahweh causing terrible things to happen is spoken of as if disaster were an object that he could bring to a place. AT: "I will cause terrible things to happen to this place and to those who live there" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will bring disaster to this place and to its inhabitants

contextId.information: Yahweh's anger is spoken of as if it were a fire that was lit. AT: "my anger against this place is like a fire that cannot be put out" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my anger has been kindled against this place, and it will not be extinguished

contextId.information: The way a person lives is spoken of as if that person were walking on a path, and "to walk after" someone is a metonym for doing what that other person does or wants others to do. AT: "live obeying Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]]
contextId.quote: walk after Yahweh

contextId.information: Fire is a metaphor for anger, and starting a fire is a metaphor for becoming angry. The abstract nouns "fierceness" and "wrath" can be translated as adjectives. This can be translated in active form. AT: "Yahweh did not turn from the fierceness of his great wrath, which he had kindled against" or "Yahweh did not stop being fierce because he was angry with" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh did not turn from the fierceness of his great wrath, which had been kindled against
